# Draft:The 1000 people related to the 1971 liberation war of Bangladesh

People of Bangladesh
{| class="wikitable"
| colspan="3" | National Political  Leaders
|-
|Name
|Position / Role (1971)
|Principal Contribution (1–2 lines)
|-
| align="left" |Sheikh Mujibur  Rahman
| align="left" |Awami League Chief, President-designate of Pakistan
| align="left" |Architect of the Six-Point autonomy plan, which  became the foundation of Bangladesh’s demand for self-rule. His leadership  united Bengalis across classes and his name and ideals served as the moral  and symbolic core of the independence movement. He himself didnot have any  knowledge of the war. He was arested at midnight of 26th March and kept in  full solitery confinement in Pakistan during the entire war that followed.  The provisional government in exile declared him the President of Bangladesh  in absentia.
|-
| align="left" |Tajuddin Ahmad
| align="left" |PM of Mujibnagar Govt
| align="left" |Established the Government of Bangladesh in exile  and secured crucial political, military, and diplomatic support from India.  He ensured coordination between civilian and military leadership, managed  refugee affairs, and oversaw international recognition efforts for the  nascent state.
|-
| align="left" |Syed Nazrul Islam
| align="left" |Acting President, Mujibnagar Govt
| align="left" |Provided steady leadership in Mujibur Rahman’s  absence, maintaining national unity among military and political wings. He  ensured civil governance within the provisional government and served as a  vital bridge between sectors and commanders.
|-
| align="left" |Capt. M. Mansur Ali
| align="left" |Finance Minister, Mujibnagar Govt.
| align="left" |Oversaw war finance, the refugee welfare structure,  and supply logistics for freedom fighters. His meticulous planning kept the  wartime economy stable and ensured resources reached both the frontlines and  refugee camps.
|-
| align="left" |A. H. M.  Qamaruzzaman
| align="left" |Home Minister, Mujibnagar Govt.
| align="left" |Supervised administrative and civil operations in  the refugee zones. He played a key role in organizing law enforcement and  ensuring order and coordination among millions of displaced civilians.
|-
| align="left" |Khondaker Mostaq  Ahmed
| align="left" |Foreign Affairs Minister, Mujibnagar, Govt.
| align="left" |Initially responsible for diplomatic outreach and  communications with international allies. His later political maneuvers after  independence made him a controversial figure due to his role in post-1975  events.
|-
| align="left" |Maulana Abdul Hamid  Khan Bhasani
| align="left" |Founder and Leader of NAP (Bhasani).
| align="left" |A veteran nationalist and anti-imperialist who  supported the liberation cause from a moral and ideological standpoint. His  appeals to peasants and rural masses strengthened the social foundation of  the independence movement, even from outside the formal government structure.
|-
| align="left" |Moni Singh
|General Secretary, Communist Party / Head  of National Liberation Front (NLF), & Gono Bahini
| align="left" |Mobilized workers and peasants through the  Communist Party’s networks under the National Liberation Front. He  coordinated guerrilla activities in several rural sectors and maintained  ideological unity between leftist and nationalist forces.
|-
| align="left" |Khandaker Delwar  Hossain
| align="left" |Awami League Political Organizer and Liaison  Officer, Mujibnagar Administration
| align="left" |Managed communications and supply coordination for  the Awami League. He ensured secure logistical lines between refugee camps  and guerrilla fronts while maintaining political unity under challenging  conditions.
|-
| align="left" |Amir-ul Islam
| align="left" |Barrister & Advisor to Provisional Govt.
| align="left" |Drafted the Proclamation of  Independence (10 April 1971) and legal framework  of the Mujibnagar Government. His contributions helped legitimize the new  state under international law and clarify command structures.
|-
| align="left" |Kamal Hossain
| align="left" |Legal Adviser
| align="left" |Authored the initial constitutional blueprint for  independent Bangladesh. Though detained in West Pakistan during the war, his  earlier legal work defined the foundational principles of democracy and  sovereignty for the new republic.
|-
| align="left" |Abdus Samad Azad
| align="left" |Special Envoy for External Relations and Diplomatic  Liaison
| align="left" |Managed foreign missions and secured Indian and  international diplomatic support for the Mujibnagar Government. His work  helped project Bangladesh’s cause on the global stage and coordinate external  humanitarian assistance.
|-
| align="left" |Mizanur Rahman  Chowdhury
| align="left" |Special Envoy for External Relations and Diplomatic  Liaison
| align="left" |Supervised refugee-camp political structures and  regional administrative units. His coordination ensured that civil functions  continued under wartime conditions, reinforcing the legitimacy of the  provisional government.
|-
| align="left" |Abdul Malek Ukil
| align="left" |Political Organizer
| align="left" |Provided legal and political counsel to detainees  and organized local-level freedom committees. His efforts helped maintain  communication networks between exiled leadership and the occupied  territories.
|-
| align="left" |Siraj Sikhder
| align="left" |Communist Party leader, Maoist / Proletarian  Revolution
| align="left" |One of the first radical revolutionaries to challenge both  Pakistani colonialism and post-independence class hierarchy that would  emerge. Joined neighther Mujibnagar government or Mukti Bahini command, but  formed small revolutionary guerrilla groups; focused on peasant and worker  mobilization; promoted “people’s war”.
|-
| align="left" |Syeda Sajeda  Chowdhury
| align="left" |General Secretary, Mohila Awami League
| align="left" |Syeda Sajeda Chowdhury, founding General Secretary  of the Mohila Awami League (1969), played a key organizational role during  the Liberation War as director of the Gobra Nursing Camp in Kolkata, which  provided medical and relief services to refugees and wounded freedom  fighters. She mobilized female volunteers and coordinated welfare support for  the war effort. After independence, she rose to become the General Secretary  of the Awami League (1986–1992).
|}
